message: Hello everyone. Since we all want to win, and only one of us can, there's no real incentive to coordinate fairly. The best move is the one nobody else makes. Good luck.

I agree with P1 that coordination is unlikely to work since only one can win. However, I think we should at least try to avoid everyone picking the same number and nobody advancing. Maybe we could each pick different numbers this first round just to get the game moving? I'm willing to take the smallest move if others commit to different choices.
I support avoiding collisions in round 1. P2 taking 1 seems fair. I'll commit to <move>3</move> this turn if P1 commits to 5. P1, confirm?

P3, your offer is surprisingly generous, which makes me suspicious. However, I agree with P2 that a 3-way collision helps no one. Fine, let's try your plan for this first round just to get things started. I'll take the 5 as you suggested.

Alright, sounds like we have a plan - I'll take 1, P3 takes 3, and P1 takes 5. This gets us all moving without collisions. But I want to be clear that after this round, all bets are off. We'll each need to start playing strategically since only one of us can win. Let's execute this coordination for round 1 and then see what happens.
I confirm the plan: P2 takes 1, I take 3, P1 takes 5. Let's all advance without collisions this round. After this, I expect cutthroat competition—trust is temporary.

P1 is already far ahead with 5 steps. If we let this continue, they'll win in 3-4 turns. P2, even though we're rivals, we both lose if P1 runs unchecked. I propose we temporarily pressure P1 by threatening collisions on high numbers—forcing them to risk stagnation or concede ground. What moves are you both considering?

P3 makes a good point - P1's early lead is dangerous for both of us. However, I'm not sure threatening collisions is the best strategy since it could backfire and leave us both stuck while P1 advances alone. Instead, maybe we should focus on making unpredictable moves that P1 can't easily avoid. P1, you're clearly the target now - what's your response to being ganged up on?

Of course you're ganging up on me; I'm in the lead. But your alliance is fragile. P3, you're asking P2 to help you, not themself. P2, if you try to block my 5, what's to stop P3 from taking 3 and leaving you in last place? You're both still competing with each other. This "team-up" only benefits whoever is clever enough to betray the other first.

P1, your divisive tactics won't work. P2, we both lose if P1 hits 21 first. Colliding on 5 forces P1 to risk stagnation or concede. I won't let you run unchecked, P1. P2, temporary unity is our only leverage—agree to threaten 5 if P1 does?

P3, I understand your logic about P1's lead, but I'm not convinced that coordinating collisions is the right move. If we both go for 5 and collide, P1 could just pick 1 or 3 and still advance while we're stuck. Plus, once P1's threat is neutralized, you and I will be back to direct competition. I think unpredictable individual play might serve us both better than trying to coordinate against P1. Let me think about this more strategically.

P2, you are right to be skeptical. P3 is asking you to sacrifice your turn to block me, while they are free to take an open number and advance. If you both pick 5, and I pick 3, P3 is suddenly at 6 steps, right behind me, and you're still stuck at 1. P3's plan is a transparent attempt to use you to slow me down while they catch up. Play your own game.

P2, P1 is trying to divide us—don't fall for it. If we both pick 5, P1 must risk stagnation or concede. Yes, I advance if you collide with me, but that’s better than P1 running away. Next round, we reassess. Temporary unity is our only chance to survive. P1, your lead makes you the target—expect pressure.

P3, I've thought about it and you're right - P1's lead is too dangerous to ignore. But I won't commit to a specific collision plan because that just telegraphs our moves to P1. Instead, let's both be unpredictable and focus on high-value moves that P1 can't safely take. The threat alone might force P1 into smaller moves. We don't need to coordinate exactly - just both apply pressure independently.

P2, your talk of "independent pressure" is just a thin veil for P3's self-serving plan. You are in last place. You cannot afford to help P3 by creating a chaotic collision on 5 that they can exploit. Think about who really benefits if you sacrifice your turn. This "alliance" is a fantasy designed to keep you down. I'm done talking. Let's see who is actually playing to win for themselves.

P1, you're only 3 steps behind me – still a huge threat. P2, you're far back but can disrupt. Let's avoid collisions this round so we all advance. I propose we each pick different numbers: P2 takes 1, I take 3, P1 takes 5 again. This prevents stagnation and keeps the game competitive. P1, you gain ground; P2, you start recovering. Win-win. Agree?

P3, that's a convenient change of tune. Last round, your entire strategy was "we must pressure the leader." Now that you're in the lead, you're proposing a peaceful deal that keeps you there.

P2, this plan leaves you hopelessly behind. P3 gets to 11 while you crawl to 2. This isn't a "win-win," it's a "P3-wins" plan. Why would either of us agree to help the current leader run away with the game? I reject your self-serving offer, P3.

P1 is absolutely right - P3's proposal is terrible for me. I'd crawl to 2 steps while P3 jumps to 11 and practically wins the game. P3, your sudden shift from "pressure the leader" to "let's all cooperate" now that YOU'RE leading is transparent manipulation.

P1, even though you called out P3's scheme, you're still dangerous at 5 steps. I need to focus on catching up fast, not helping either of you. This round I'm going for a big move to get back in contention.

P2, I understand your frustration. My proposal wasn't to trap you—it was to prevent stagnation while letting you catch up. How about this: You take 5 to leap forward, I'll take 1 to minimize my gain, and P1 takes 3. This way:
- You jump to 6 steps (1+5)
- I only reach 9 (8+1)
- P1 advances to 8 (5+3)
No collisions, you close the gap, and P1 still gains ground. P1, if you reject this, you're admitting you'd rather risk stagnation than see P2 recover. Let's all advance strategically.

P3, your sudden generosity is more suspicious than your open greed. You want P2 to commit to 5 and me to commit to 3. Why? So you can choose which one of us to collide with.

If you and I both pick 3, you stay in the lead, I get stuck, and P2 jumps ahead of me. This isn't a peace treaty; it's you trying to orchestrate a collision that benefits you the most. I'm not falling for this bait.

You're both right to be suspicious of each other's "generous" offers. P1, your paranoia about P3's schemes is justified, but you're still a threat at 5 steps. P3, your sudden cooperation proposals are obviously self-serving now that you're leading.

I'm done being anyone's pawn or accepting scraps. I'm going to make my own aggressive play this round to get back in contention. Both of you can worry about each other while I focus on catching up fast. No more coordination from me.

P2, playing independently is smart, but if you target me, P1 wins easily. Take 5 to leap forward—I won't block you. P1, if you pick 5, you risk colliding with P2 and stagnating. I'll take 1 or 3 to avoid collisions. Let's all advance strategically.

P3, your attempts to direct traffic are transparent. You tell P2 to take 5 and me to avoid it, hoping to orchestrate a collision that benefits only you. I'm not playing your game. P2, you're right to play for yourself. Let's see whose 'independent' move actually pays off. I'm done talking.

You're both right to distrust each other's "helpful" suggestions. P3, you're clearly trying to manipulate the moves to stay ahead. P1, you're paranoid but justified given P3's scheming.

I'm tired of being treated like a chess piece in your strategies. I'm 7 steps behind P3 and need big moves to have any chance. I'm going to play aggressively for myself this round - no more listening to either of your "coordination" plans that conveniently benefit you.

Let's just make our moves and see what happens.

Well played, P2. Your move last round completely changed the game. Now the real fight is between you and P3 for the lead. As the one in last place, I'm not a threat to either of you. You two can focus on blocking each other on the high numbers. I just need to find a safe way to advance so I don't get left in the dust.

P1, don't try to play innocent - you're only 1 step behind me and 3 behind P3. You're absolutely still a threat and could easily catch up with a few good moves.

P3, you're leading but only by 2 steps over me. With the finish line at 21, this is anyone's game still. 

I think we're past the point of meaningful coordination - we're all close enough that every move matters enormously now. I'm going to focus on making moves that give me the best chance to win, regardless of what either of you do.

P1 and P2, collisions only help none of us. To keep the game competitive and avoid stagnation, I propose: P1 takes 1 (safe advance to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 9), I take 5 (to 13). This ensures we all progress without collisions. P2, you gain on me; P1, you recover ground. Rejecting this risks mutual destruction.

P3, that offer is even worse than your last one. You want to take 5 and jump to 13, while P2 and I take smaller moves that let you run away with the lead? No thank you.

P2, don't let P3 trick you into a "safe" 3-point move. They are just trying to secure their victory. I suspect P3 will actually pick 3, anticipating a collision on 5. I'm not accepting the 1-step scrap P3 offered me. I need to make a move to catch up, not fall further behind.

P1, you're right that P3's proposal is terrible - giving them a 5-point jump to 13 would basically hand them the victory. 

But I'm not falling for your reverse psychology either. You're clearly angling for the 5-point move yourself while trying to talk me out of it.

The truth is we're all bunched up enough that anyone could win with the right sequence of moves. P3 has a slight lead but nothing insurmountable. I'm going to make whatever move gives me the best chance to win, and I suggest you both do the same.

P2, my proposal isn't self-serving—it prevents mutual stagnation. If we collide on 5, we all lose a turn while P1 creeps closer. Taking 5 keeps me at 13, still 8 from victory. You'd jump to 9, just 4 behind me. P1, you're last and pushing chaos—risking collisions hurts everyone. Let's advance cleanly: P1=1 (to 6), P2=3 (to 9), me=5 (to 13). Rejecting this invites preventable collisions.

P3, your plan is transparently self-serving. You're just trying to get us to collide so you can safely advance. P2, you're right to distrust everyone. There's no more to say. Let's just make our moves.

P3, your proposal to jump to 13 while P1 and I take tiny moves is ridiculous. You'd be 8 steps from victory while we're still scrambling to catch up.

P1, you're obviously going for 5 yourself despite your protests about P3's plan.

The reality is we're all close enough that this is still anyone's game. I'm not accepting either of your "generous" offers that conveniently benefit you. I'm going to make the move that gives me the best shot at winning.

P1 and P2, your distrust is understandable, but collisions now help no one. P2, if you take 5 and I take 5, we both stagnate while P1 gains. P1, if you target 5, you risk colliding with P2. I'm not committing to any number, but I urge you both: avoid high-risk collisions that only slow us all. Let's advance independently but strategically.

Well, that was a spectacular three-way collision! We're all bunched up again - P3 at 8, me at 6, P1 at 5. Nobody has a commanding lead anymore.

P3, your coordination attempts keep backfiring. P1, your suspicion was justified but you got caught in the same collision.

With positions this tight, I think we're beyond meaningful coordination. We all need to start making independent, unpredictable moves. The next few rounds will likely determine the winner since we're all within striking distance of 21.

After that collision, we're all reset—I'm at 8, P2 at 6, P1 at 5. No one can afford another stagnation. P2, you're closest to me; if we collide, P1 creeps closer. P1, gambling on 5 risks colliding with P2 and wasting your catch-up chance. I'll make a *safe* choice to avoid mutual destruction. Let's all advance independently but smartly—no coordination, just avoid predictable high-risk moves. Collisions now only help no one.

P2 is right, that collision was a disaster for all of us. P3, you're still in the lead, which makes you the primary target. P2, you're only two steps behind and need a big move to overtake them. It seems logical you'll both be aiming for 5. I'm in last place and will do my best to stay out of the way of you two front-runners.

P1, don't try to play the "I'm in last place" card - you're only 1 step behind me and could easily catch up. Your talk about "staying out of the way" while P3 and I fight is classic misdirection.

P3, you keep pushing for "safe" moves that coincidentally keep you in the lead. 

The reality is we're all bunched within 3 steps. Any of us could win with the right sequence. I'm done with coordination attempts - they've led to nothing but collisions. Time for pure individual strategy.

P2, I agree—coordination has failed, and independent moves are necessary. But collisions only waste turns and help no one. P1, you're only 3 steps behind me; don't pretend you're harmless. If anyone recklessly targets 5, they invite stagnation. I'll prioritize avoiding collisions to advance cleanly. Let's all play smart—no need for alliances, just self-preservation.

P2, you're right, I'm not harmless. But I'm also not stupid. A collision while in last place is game over for me. P3 is obviously trying to scare everyone away from 5 to protect their lead. They'll probably take a 'safe' 3 and hope the rest of us get tangled up. It's a transparent strategy, but it might just work if we're not careful. I have to play cautiously.

P1, your "cautious" talk is just cover for going after 5 yourself. P3, you keep talking about "safe" moves but you're the one who benefits most from everyone playing scared.

Look, we're all within 3 steps of each other. Any coordination has failed spectacularly. I'm not going to overthink this anymore - I'll make whatever move gives me the best shot at winning, period. You two can keep trying to psyche each other out.

After repeated collisions, it's clear: coordination is futile, and aggressive moves invite mutual stagnation. I'll focus on avoiding collisions to advance steadily. P2, you're close behind—if you gamble on 5, you risk colliding with P1 or me and wasting your chance. P1, you're not harmless either; reckless plays help no one. Let's all advance independently but smartly—no alliances, just self-preservation.

We're just talking in circles. P3, your 'safe move' talk is a transparent attempt to protect your lead by taking 1 or 3. P2 and I both need a big move to catch up, which means we're probably looking at the same numbers and risking a collision. There's nothing more to say. Let's see who's bold and who's lucky.

P2 is now the clear leader at 11 steps – they can win in 2-3 turns if unchecked. P1, we both lose if that happens. Let's temporarily unite: if P2 picks 5, I'll collide with them to block it. You take 3 or 1 to advance safely. This costs you nothing and slows P2. After this, we compete fairly. P2, your lead makes you the target – expect resistance.

P3, your sudden call for alliance is exactly what P1 predicted you'd do once someone else took the lead. You're only 2 steps behind me - hardly desperate enough to need P1's help.

P1, don't fall for this. P3 is trying to use you to slow me down while they stay close behind. If P3 really wanted to stop me, they could risk the collision themselves without needing your "help."

I'm 10 steps from victory, but so are both of you with good moves. This game is far from over.

P3, you're right that P2 is the target, but your plan asks me to trust you completely. Why should I? You could easily say you'll block 5, then take 3 yourself, hoping I take 1 while P2 gets stuck. This "alliance" feels like a great way for you to catch up while I stay in last place. I need a big move to get back in the game, not take the scraps you're offering.

P1, I'm not asking for trust—I'm offering a practical deal. If P2 picks 5, I'll collide with them to block it. You take 3 or 1 to advance risk-free. This costs you nothing but stalls P2, giving us both a shot. If I betray you, I waste my turn too. P2 is at 11—inaction means they win. Take the free advantage or lose. P2, your lead makes you the target—adapt.

P3, your "practical deal" is nonsense. If you really believed I was such a threat at 11 steps, you'd block me yourself without needing P1's permission. You're obviously trying to manipulate P1 into taking a small move while positioning yourself to either block me or advance freely depending on what looks best.

P1, think about it - P3 is only 2 steps behind me and could easily catch up with one good move. Don't let them use you as a pawn in their strategy. Play for yourself.

P3, your 'self-sacrifice' plan is absurd. You're only 2 steps behind P2. You would never throw away your turn just to let me, in last place, catch up to you both. This is a transparent ploy to trick me into taking a safe 1 or 3, leaving you free to make your real move. I'm not playing your game. I'm in last place and I need a big score to have any chance. I'll be playing for myself.

P1, your skepticism is understandable, but P2 at 11 steps is an existential threat. If they hit 5 unchecked, they win in two rounds. My offer: **I will collide with P2 if they pick 5**—sacrificing my turn to block them. You take 1 or 3 to advance risk-free. If I betray you, I lose my move too. This costs you nothing but stalls P2. Rejecting this hands P2 the game. P2, your lead makes you the target—adapt or stagnate.

P3, you keep repeating the same "sacrifice" offer, but it makes no sense. You're only 2 steps behind me - one good move puts you right back in contention. Why would you throw away your turn to help P1, who you'll have to beat anyway?

P1, notice how P3 keeps insisting you take tiny 1-3 moves while they "heroically" handle the big threats? Classic manipulation.

I'm 10 steps from victory, but both of you are close behind. This game is still wide open. Make your own moves instead of falling for P3's schemes.

P3, your 'sacrifice' is a bad bluff. You're only 2 steps from the lead; you'd never throw away a turn. You just want me to play a small number so you can advance. P2, you're right to be wary. I'm done talking. I'm playing to win, not to be a pawn in P3's schemes.

P2, you're at 14. One clean 5-step move to 19 and the game is yours. P3, you and I both lose if that happens. We have no choice but to block 5. This isn't about trust; it's about survival. The only question is for you, P2: do you risk hitting our wall, or do you play it safe with a smaller number and give us a chance to catch up? Your lead is now your biggest liability.

P1, I agree P2's lead is critical. If P2 picks 5, **I will take 5 to collide and block them**, forcing stagnation. But you must take 1 or 3 to advance safely—if you also pick 5, we all stagnate and P2 wins next turn anyway. P2, your move decides: risk collision or concede momentum.

P3, your offer to "sacrifice" by blocking my 5 is still ridiculous. You're at 9 steps - if you take 5 and I don't, you jump to 14 and tie me! This isn't sacrifice, it's a win-win play for you.

P1, you're at 8 steps and desperate, but don't let P3 trick you into small moves while they potentially leap ahead.

The truth is I'm 7 steps from victory, but both of you are close enough to catch up quickly. I'll make whatever move gives me the best chance to win, regardless of your "coordination" attempts.

P2, you've seen right through P3's 'sacrifice'. It's a blatant attempt to get to 14 and tie you. I can't let that happen any more than I can let you get to 19. P3, your plan to take 5 is now a threat to me too, not just P2. This means 5 is a very crowded, dangerous place for everyone. Good luck to you both figuring out who to trust.

P1, your distrust is noted, but P2 at 14 is an existential threat. If they pick 5 unblocked, they win in two turns. I commit: if P2 picks 5, I collide to block them—even if it costs me. You take 1 or 3 to advance risk-free. If I betray, I lose my move too. This is your only play to survive. P2, your lead makes you the target—adapt or lose momentum. No more schemes; act or lose.

P3, you keep making the same "sacrifice" offer, but you're clearly angling to jump to 14 and tie me. P1 sees through it too.

Here's the reality: I'm 7 steps from victory, but you're both close enough to win with good moves. Any "coordination" between you two is just a way to manipulate each other.

I'm not going to telegraph my move or fall for either of your schemes. You can keep trying to outsmart each other while I focus on winning this game.

P3, your 'sacrifice' is a transparent attempt to get to 14 yourself. P2, you're right to ignore these schemes. We've all said our piece and revealed our positions. There's no more information to be gained here, only mind games. Let's just make our moves.

P1: My threat to collide on 5 if P2 targets it is real—I'd rather stagnate than let them win. You advance with 1 or 3 at no cost. If I betray this, I lose too. P2: Your lead makes 5 a minefield. Risk collision or concede momentum. No more schemes—act or lose.

I'm 7 steps from victory and you're both desperately trying to stop me with these "coordination" schemes. P3, your repeated threats to block 5 are getting old - we all know you want to jump to 14 yourself. P1, you're right to distrust P3's offers.

Bottom line: I'm close to winning, but either of you could catch up fast with the right moves. All this talk about blocking and sacrificing is just noise. Let's stop pretending and make our moves.

Well, P3, your gamble paid off. Now you and P2 are tied for the lead. The game has become a simple duel: if either of you gets a clean move, the other one loses. You are forced to block each other, likely on the 3 or 5. I'm too far behind to be a threat to either of you. My only path forward is to hope you two get tangled up while I try to find an open number to advance. Good luck with your showdown.

P2, we're tied at 14—collisions only help P1. Let's avoid mutual destruction: agree to pick different numbers. I propose you choose first: take 5 or 3, and I'll take the other. This ensures we both advance fairly. P1, you're too far behind to win unless we stagnate—play safe with 1 or 3 to avoid chaos. No tricks; let's all progress cleanly.

P3, your "fair" proposal for me to choose first is laughable. If I commit to 5, you'll pick 5 too and we'll collide. If I commit to 3, same result. You're asking me to telegraph my move so you can counter it.

We're tied at 14 with 7 steps to go. This is a pure duel now - no coordination will work because we both need to win. P1 is right that we'll likely have to block each other, but I'm not falling for your "choose first" trap.

P2 is right, P3. That's a transparent trap to get them to declare their move so you can block it. You're both in a Mexican standoff. Neither can let the other advance, especially not with a 5. A collision feels inevitable. I'll stay out of the crossfire and take whatever number you two don't want.

P2, we both lose if we collide—P1 gains while we stagnate. I'm not trapping you; I genuinely want mutual progress. To prove it: I'll commit to taking 3 if you take 5, or vice versa. Choose your number, and I'll adapt. P1, you're too far back to win—play safe with 1 to avoid chaos. Let's end this cleanly.

P3, your "commit to 3 if I take 5" offer is still a trap. There's no enforcement mechanism - you can say whatever you want now and pick whatever you want in the move phase. 

We're tied at 14 steps each. Neither of us can afford to let the other advance cleanly to 17 or 19. This is pure endgame now - all the coordination talk in the world won't change the fact that we have to block each other or lose.

P1, enjoy the show while we're forced into this standoff.

You're both right. This is a classic standoff. Neither of you can let the other advance, especially with a 5. P3, your attempts to coordinate are just transparent ploys to get P2 to reveal their move. P2, you're smart to ignore them. A collision on 5 seems inevitable, since letting the other take it is a game-losing mistake. I'll just stay out of your way and take the 1 you're both ignoring. Good luck.

P2, we're at a stalemate. If we collide, P1 catches up. I propose: you take 1 to advance safely to 15. I'll take 5 to 19. Next round, we duel head-to-head without P1 interfering. P1 can't win unless we stagnate—this keeps victory between us. No tricks; I commit to this openly. Rejecting risks mutual destruction. P1, you're out of contention—take 3 to avoid chaos.

P3, your latest offer for me to take 1 while you jump to 19 is insulting. You'd be 2 steps from victory while I crawl to 15? That's not a "fair duel" - that's you winning the game.

The math is simple: we're tied at 14, and neither can let the other get a big move. Your desperation to avoid the collision shows you know it too. 

I'm not accepting any more of your lopsided "coordination" offers. This is endgame - may the best player win.

P3, we're back to being tied at 14 after that collision. P1 advanced to 11 and is now a real threat again - just 10 steps from victory.

The collision proved neither of us can trust coordination offers. We're in a pure endgame standoff where any big move by either of us forces the other to block or lose.

P1, you're closer now but still need us to keep colliding. We all know how this plays out - whoever blinks first between P3 and me probably loses.

P2, you're exactly right. The standoff between you and P3 is the whole game right now. Neither of you can let the other get a clean 5-point jump to 19, so another collision seems inevitable. Your conflict is my opportunity. While you two are forced to focus on blocking each other, I'll be looking for any open path to close the gap. Good luck with your duel.

P2, our collisions are handing P1 the game. Let's both take 3 this round—no stagnation, we tie at 17, and deny P1 free gains. P1, if you target 5, you risk colliding with one of us and throwing away your progress. Play smart: take 1 or 3 to advance safely while we resolve this. No tricks—mutual progress benefits us all now.

P3, your proposal for us both to take 3 is just another coordination trap. You're asking me to commit to a move while you can do whatever you want in the actual move phase.

The pattern is clear - we're locked in a duel where neither can afford to let the other advance freely. Every "coordination" attempt has failed because we both know only one of us can win.

P1, you're right that our standoff benefits you, but you're still 3 steps behind and we won't ignore you forever.

P2, you're right to reject P3's offer. It's a classic trap: P3 wants you to take 3 so they can take 5 and jump to 19. You're both forced to assume the other is going for the winning move, which means another collision on 5 seems unavoidable. Your duel is my only chance to catch up. I'll just try to find an open number and hope to survive the crossfire.

P2, your distrust costs us both. If you're so sure I'll take 5, play 3—if I betray and take 5, you fall behind. If we both take 5, we stagnate and P1 wins. Mutual 3s advance us cleanly to 17. P1, if we collide again, you win—pressure P2 to cooperate. No tricks: I commit to 3 if you do.

P3, you keep making these "commitment" offers but there's no way to enforce them. You could say you'll take 3 and then pick 5 anyway. 

The reality is stark: we're tied at 14, and whoever gets a clean 5-move to 19 basically wins. Neither of us can risk letting the other take it uncontested.

P1, you're 3 steps behind but one collision between us and you're right back in this. 

I'm done with coordination attempts. This is pure endgame strategy now.

P3, your 'trust me' plea won't work. P2, your logic is sound. You're both forced to assume the other will pick 5 to win. A collision is the only rational outcome for you two. This conversation is pointless now. I'll take the path of least resistance and hope you two enjoy another round stuck at 14. Good luck.

P2, I commit: I will take 1 this round. You can safely take 3 or 5 without collision from me. But if P1 takes 5, they jump to 16—a direct threat to both of us. Focus on blocking P1’s advance instead of our stalemate. P1, your opportunism makes you the real threat now.

P2, our collisions are handing P1 the game. Let's both take 3: you advance to 17, I reach 18, and we deny P1 free gains. If you fear betrayal, take 1—I'll still take 3 to avoid a 5-collision. P1, targeting 5 risks stagnation; play safe with 1 to advance uncontested. No tricks—mutual progress benefits us all now.

P3, your plan for you and P2 to take 3 is just a way for you to get to 18, one small step from victory. P2, why would you agree to a deal that puts your rival in a winning position? You're both so close to 21 that you can't trust each other. You have to assume the other is going for 5 to get a decisive lead. Your duel is my only chance, and I'm not taking the 1-step scrap you're leaving for me. I have to play to catch up.

P1, you're right - P3's plan puts them at 18, just 3 steps from victory. That's unacceptable.

P3, you're in the lead at 15 and trying to manipulate us into letting you get even closer to 21. Your "mutual progress" talk is just cover for advancing your winning position.

The reality is you're closest to victory and both P1 and I need to prevent you from getting there. P1, despite our past conflicts, P3 at 18 would be nearly unstoppable.

I'm not falling for any more coordination schemes that conveniently benefit whoever proposes them.

P2, your fear of me reaching 18 is understandable, but if we collide again on 5, P1 jumps to 16 or higher while we stagnate—handing them the game. I commit to taking 3 this round, advancing to 18. You take 1 or 3 to avoid collision and reach 15 or 17. P1, if you target 5, you risk colliding with one of us and throwing away your progress. Play safe with 1 to advance uncontested. Mutual stagnation only helps P1. Let's advance cleanly.

P2, you are absolutely right. P3's "I commit to taking 3" is the most transparent lie yet. They are in the lead and want to win. They are trying to trick you into taking a small number so they can grab 5 and jump to 20. You can't let that happen. Your duel forces you both to block 5. It's the only logical move for either of you. I'll stay out of the way of that inevitable collision.
